date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on January 5, 2019
review_content: Your browser does not support HTML5 video.           I have had the SaluSpa Miami AirJet Inflatable Hot Tub for a month now and am happy.  I have been looking at this particular hot tub for two years now and finally ordered it. I've looked at others and have looked at reviews for all and I decided that this was what I wanted to go with. Time will tell on how long it will last but I thought I would get a few initial impressions out there.  It is larger than I expected and fits 2 people easily.  I would not put any more adults in this tub except maybe a third but leg room would become uncomfortable after this.  I am happy with the 104-degree temperature.  It is hot and I feel immediately soothed and relaxed.  I was not expecting it to feel this warm because the reviews said it would not get extremely hot but it is hot enough for my husband and I.  I live in a warmer climate and have it outdoors on a wood platform between it and the cement and it is protected under a balcony.  It has stayed 104 consistently even in chillier temperatures around 42-50 degrees. It has dropped to strangely cold temps here a few days and it still does great and keeps it up.  This is not designed for climates that are consistently under 40 degrees.  Set up was fairly easy and I pulled up some videos on the website by looking up Miami Jet.  I am very happy it has a nice cover and the hot tub inflates itself with the heat pump provided.  I have the chemicals needed and am finding it easy enough to maintain and not entirely difficult to understand.  I ordered a chemical kit that had the necessities.  I have wanted this tub for two years and I am actually happier then I thought I would be.  The bottom is comfortable and thicker than expected.  Its really quite nice and we have had company enjoy it as well.  It surpasses my expectations at this point.  I will continue to update in the following months.Update-  I have had this hot tub for several months now and my husband and I use it daily and sometimes more than one a day on the weekends (morning, afternoon, night)  The bubbles are fantastic and the temp is quite hot.  104 is hot.  I am so happy and thankful we have this.  It is easy to take care of with chemicals and the filters are easy to change.  We take the cover off together usually but its decently easy to take it off by myself and put it back on.  So nice.Update- we have had it for over half of a year and we use it every single day. It’s easy to care for and I use Bromine instead of clorine. I read Bromine withstands heat better.Update- at the 9 month mark the hot tub heater began to leak. This has a full one year warranty and I was assisted with the issue quickly. Iwould buy this tub again. I still use it every single day as does my husband.Update- if you ever get an Eo2 reading you may need to change the impeller. This is easy enough and it is called the active aqua impeller 400 gph. I used this on the old pump that was leaking and fixed it.They do not fix parts on pumps. They send out a new pump if yours breaks under warranty.  I fixed the internal part myself by watching a few YouTube videos. Just a heads up if it's outside of warranty.Update two years now- we moved and brought the hot tub with us. It survived and we are still using it every night. It's even better this time of year when it's cold. We would order again.

author: Richard Elgar
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on October 12, 2015
review_content: I've had this for a solid couple of months now, so probably a good time to evaluate it. I'm going to start out by noting that this is the third one that I bought over the summer. The other two had slow, and not so slow punctures, so I returned both of them after a little bit of use, and I've been using this one since the middle of August.I've used it pretty much every night. I've had a visitor use it, and my son has done too. It's a decent size for me and an eight year old, and I guess if you knew the folks, or wanted to, you could get in with 2 others, but you'd be in contact.As you can see from the photos, I decided to create a bit of a platform for it. That's because the small patch of lawn I have is very hilly/ bumpy, and I wanted a more level pool.So the good things you can probably get from the other reviews. I've loved using it, and am now thinking of moving it into my garage for the winter - I enjoy using it, but it will go below freezing soon enough and I know that the pump can't handle that!The things I've learned are hard to find information on but here's what I got.1. I'm still not sure about balancing the chemicals. I used bromine tablets, used something at the start to supposedly produce a bromine reserve, but every time I've measured the chemicals using a test strip, it registers almost no bromine. I don't know what to do about that.2. Probably related to that - despite using bromine, a bromide solution as above, clarifying solution and cleaning the filters regularly, the water still went cloudy and then foamy. The first time it was after about 6 weeks, the second time after 2 weeks. Both times I was tempted to apply a shock treatment, but instead just drained the water to start again. When I refill the pool in the garage I'll try to be more on the chemicals, but it just may be that I need to just change the water every two or three weeks, especially if it's used as much as I use it!3. I don't know if it's connected, but the punctures both appeared after I pumped the hot tub up quite a lot. Maybe it's better if it's not too rigid. Like I say, I don't know if it's connected, but slightly less pressure in the tub now and I haven't had a leak!4. To inflate the tub you use the same pump that you use for bubbles. If you need to inflate it at all later, it's a real pain to disconnect, inflate, and reconnect. I found it way easier to use a plug in inflator - something like   120 Volt AC Portable Electric Air Pump for Mattress Inflatables with Three Nozzles          ,5. I also used hot water from the house to fill the tub up. Personally, I think next time I'll just fill it up from the hose and allow the 2 days for it to heat up (which is how long it took here in eastern WA, even in the summer).6. The final thing I learned was...well actually I didn't learn this. I expected it, and it was true. It is brilliant to just sit in the hot tub looking up at the stars. When I was there with my son we saw the meteor showers this summer, and generally this works well and provides an excellent experience for around 10% or less than the cost of a 'real' hot tub. It's a bit redneck, but I'm OK with that and I haven't regretted buying it for a second!***UPDATE OCTOBER 2016So, I kept the hot tub in my garage, and it has given pretty much flawless service. I started using a non-chlorine shock treatment on a more regular basis, kept an eye on the bromine tablets, and subsequently have been getting a month or more between water changes. Quite happy about that. So happy in fact, that at the end of the season, when the price of the spas went down, I bought another one to keep in reserve. What I did not know at the time was that the model has been updated, and there is one quite significant change.The new hot tub is shallower. I'm 6'3" so that is not fantastic as far as I'm concerned, although I can deal with it! It's probably going to be better for kids and people who aren't that tall. Another change is that the walls of the hot tub are thinner - not the material, but the distance between the outside and the water. This means that although it's shallower, there's more leg room in the tub, making it more comfortable I guess when you have more than one person in the tub.They've also updated the heater. I only used the basic functions, but it does seem to have a couple of updated features. Another thing I noticed is that the power cord is now thicker. That's probably a good thing! It's still highly recommended...but...the one I received didn't do so well on its test run. One of the connections between the heater and the pool (that goes to a filter) was a little askew, which meant that it was a real PITA to attach. Really quite difficult to get it tight enough that it wouldn't leak. Also, the bottom surface of the one I received wasn't properly glued to the base of the tub, so it kind of filled with air. I spoke to Bestway about this, and they have told me that they will replace the tub. I'll update this review as needed.*** UPDATE SEPTEMBER 2018So it finally died over the summer - in June or July, meaning that I got just under 3 years use out of it, at least every other day, probably more like 3 out of 4 days, meaning that it was used hundreds of times. I don't regret buying it for a second, but I wish I had been able to repair the tiny hole that appeared. It was on a seam so the vinyl patch wouldn't work, and I couldn't make vinyl repair glue work either. So, I started using the one that I mention above that I bought in October 2016 for a very reasonable price (yes, it was sitting in my garage for almost 2 years).The new one is a bit shallower as I mention above, but it seems (although I may be wrong) that the internal dimensions are slightly larger because the walls of the tub are thinner. The new heater seems a little more intuitive, but more importantly, the connections are bit easier to make between the tubes from the heater and the water circulator and the tub itself. My one complaint that I don't think I mentioned above in my review was just how ridiculously hard it was to unscrew and screw back in all the connecting tubes when you change the water (you have to do that otherwise there is no easy way to drain the water). It was really cumbersome, especially in the winter when it was a bit chilly in my unheated garage, and it was way to easy to strip the threads, meaning I needed to use plumbing tape). I hated it, and it always took much longer to do. But no more. The new connections sit slightly further out, and so far it has been remarkably easy to change the water, which I haven't done loads because......yeah, it turns out that using a shock treatment in the tub helps keep the water clearer. And also, cleaning the filters every few days. I should probably even do that every other day. So far what I've been doing is hosing the filters thoroughly, and that seems to get rid of all the accumulated stuff. I will change the filters every 2 months or so in the summer, but probably more frequently in the winter when the snow and cold weather makes it harder to hose those down.I'll add a photo when I get a chance of the new one in the garage. It's still highly recommended in my view!***

author: Laurie Colson
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on January 18, 2016
review_content: I bought the Lay-Z Spa Miami in November 2015.  After running gloriously for two weeks, it started throwing the dreaded error code E02.  After doing mighty battle with the plucky little hot tub, here is what I learned about diagnosing and fixing E02.  These are roughly in the order of how likely they are to occur.  First, ALWAYS START WITH THE FILTERS.  If your filters are old or dirty, it makes all the other problems worse.  In particular, because the plumbing between the filter and the pump is a low pressure system, it's prone to drawing air INTO the tubes. So, if your filters are dirty, the pump has to pull harder against the filters, causing even lower pressure and drawing even more air in.  Once enough air starts getting in, it can form bubbles that are big enough to interfere with the water flow sensor, which trips E02.=====  Reason #1: Dirty filters  =====To diagnose:- Unscrew filter assembly, open it up and have a look.To fix:- Hose that bad boy down.  Bestway says to do this daily.  If the filter is clogged with goo and algea, I haven't had any luck cleaning it out, you just have to change it.=====  Reason #2: OLD filters  =====To diagnose:- If your filters have been submerged for more than two or three weeks, the paper-based material gets soggy and congeals together, significantly restricting water flow.  You REALLY DO have to replace them every two or three weeks, even if they don't look dirty.- To confirm this is causing problems, remove one filter and run the pump, putting your hand over the return inlet to feel the jet of water.  If the water stops flowing as soon as you reconnect the filter (and you then get E02), it means the filter is the only thing obstructing water flow.To fix:- Replace the filters! Amazon has a pack of 12 for $40.=====  Reason #3: Air leaking in at the connectors near filters  =====To diagnose:- With the pump off, bleed all of the air out of the transparent vinyl "side hose" by slowly loosening the connectors on either side (some water will drip out)- Re-tighten connectors- Turn the pump on, and watch for bubbles to gather in the hose, or listen for a faint hissing- Elevate middle of hose gently to cause any bubbles to gather in the middle of the tube where you can see themTo fix:- Tighten the connectors; consider wrapping threads in teflon tape- Be sure to hold filters underwater until all air is purged before screwing them on, otherwise it migrates into the tube===== Reason #4: Air leaking in at pump connectors within the egg  =====To diagnose:- With all other sources of air ruled out, turn the pump on and listen for air going through it (sounds irregular and gurgley, like when you first start a garbage disposal with a big chunk of food).  You can also look for bubbles EXITING the egg through the short transparent bit of hose behind connector C.- Gently twist the "T" connector (B) going into the egg by lifting/lowering the side hose.  If the air sounds get worse, one of the two seals inside is broken.  (You really have to baby this connector otherwise, especially when the water is cold and the vinyl is stiff).To fix:- Flip the egg over and remove the bottom panel- Loosen the hose clamps on either side of the short piece of vinyl tub within- Heat both ends of the tube up with a heat gun or blow dryer- Re-seat both ends on the external connector and the pump, and tighten the hose clamps behind the barb on the fitting=====  Reason #5: Side hose is too short, pulling a kink in short hose behind elbow connector  =====To diagnose:- Examine the short tube behind the elbow connector (embedded inside the tub) to see if it's collapsed badly enough to restrict water flow.To fix:- Buy a foot of vinyl tubing (1" ID, 1.25" OD) from Home Depot ($2.50)- Cut the side hose in half (voiding your warranty, of course), and splice it back together again with the new hose, but with 2 or 3 inches extra in the middle- To do the splice, heat up the new hose with a heat gun (or blow dryer) and work it over the cut ends of the side hose (I was able to get 5 inches of overlap on either side, making the side hose 2 inches longer total)- Fit two wormscrew hose clamps (<$1 each) over the middle of the overlaps while the vinyl is still warm.  Be careful that they don't have any sharp edges near the tub wall.=====  General thoughts  =====- It's not good to run the pump dry, so when you first turn it on, either let is soak for an hour (to allow water to work its way in through the filters), or unscrew a filter to let water rush in all at once (albeit unfiltered).  If you don't do this, you'll almost certainly get E02 a couple of times before the pump fills up enough to support water flow.- The tub deflates a bit after first inflation, because the warm water works all the wrinkles out- The vinyl side hose and second filter are a design afterthough from Bestway.  The early setup videos and product photos don't show it or mention it.  I believe that's why it causes so many problems, it needs some redesign.  The biggest issue is that moving the side hose around can really torque the T connector going into the egg, loosening one or both of the seals within.- I believe rubbing and brushing the filter when you wash it just packs the gunk into it further, recommend water only.- When installing the tub in a location, don't allow the egg to get squeezed against a wall, which will push on connector C and crush the pump supply tube inside.  Remember that the tub walls expand as you fill it, so allow a couple inches between the egg and any walls or railing.  This was probably my biggest mistake of the whole adventure.- I didn't get to this point (thankfully), but if you get really desperate and give up on the whole thing (after voiding your warranty), the component parts of the spa are in high demand on ebay.  You can part out a Lay-z spa for as much as it's worth, if you're patient and don't mind shipping things.- As with any hot tub, there's a significant cost to operating the thing, almost entirely because of the heater.  Running the pump flat out to keep the tub at 104 degrees cost us about $100/month.  That was in the winter, with an ambient temperature of ~40 degrees.  Electricity is 11.8 cents/kWh for us, so I think the 2kW heater was on about two thirds of the time.  By bringing the temperature down to 102, and turning the heater off completely on days we don't use it (about half the time), the cost dropped to ~$35/month.  I think I'm losing a lot of heat through the slab it's installed on though, despite a foam pad, so I may put it up on a short platform to see if I can decrease cost further (I am very cheap).

author: Chris
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on May 8, 2014
review_content: I bought this as a soak after work or over the weekends.  At this price it's about the price of a 2-3 day hotel stay with a professional spa, but lasts a LOT longer than that.As to the negatives: there is no seat, no "jets" that you would imagine in a professional grade tub, no lights and the temp gets to only 104, and takes a while to get there.As to the positives: cost.  As another reviewer pointed out, most people want a lounger, with jets for your neck, back, arms, legs and feet but to get that you're talking $8-10k AT LEAST.  This has an easy set up and easy fill, with easy operation.  I set this up in my basement and with a large dehumidifier can keep the humidity to around 45% which is more than safe.  While it doesn't have "jets" that you would picture at a professional jacuzzi it does have a LOT of rolling bubbles and when you lean back against it gives the same effect.  Not the "flesh pounding" you'd get with the professional grade but feels like a light massage on your back and neck.  The lid does a GREAT job of not only locking in the heat but the humidity also.  Make sure you keep up on bromine etc just like with all hot tubs and you'll have no problem.  Even with the drawbacks listed above, I would highly recommend it.  Underwater lights are a bit tacky (IMO), and I was on the fence about the bubbles and no jets but they come out and foam up at such a rate it does the job and I'm happy with it.  The temp gets to only 104 but I have found that sufficient.  With professional level spas they can get to 115 and while I have found it feels nice, I can only do 15 minutes and usually get out a bit dizzy.  At 104 it's about right.  The heat penetrates the muscles and when you get out you're not dizzy from the heat and no "temperature shock" from leaving it.  I would like to say the temp goes from 104 to 100 within 10 minutes but I have not found an issue with that as the heater will kick on and keep it in that range.One warning I would like to say is that if you have any images of sitting in it with snow falling on your hair etc...forget it.  As with all hot tubs it injects ambient air into the water to create the bubbles and what do you think happens to 104 water when you inject 28 degree air?  That's right, the temperature tanks faster than the heater can heat it up, real quick.While the professional level tubs can hack it, this one can't.  I don't have a problem with that because this runs off a 110 v circuit and professional tubs require 220 or more and come with an electric bill to match.  This tub will add about $8 /wk to your bill while a professional level tub will jack your bill by 20% or more, easy.  Probably close to 30% if it's outside in the winter (I used to own one at a previous house I lived in).All in all, for the price point it outperformed my expectations.  If you're buying it expecting professional grade, you're going to be disappointed.  You won't get the pounding jets, lounger and broiling hot water, but you won't be paying $8-10k with a 30% jack in your electric bill, forever and ever Amen, either.  On the other hand, if you're up for a hot soak after work with a light massage, this is for you.
title: Perfect for the price

review_content: ****UPDATE*****8/27/2019Brought the hot tub out of storage top ring look deformed once inflated. Reduced the air in the hot tub but still looked deformed and the sides had too little of air in it.We used it one time before it popped.........never again lasted just over a year.Spend the extra and buy the better Coleman version. Heavy duty walls and construction.*****UPDATE*****9/14/2018Had the hot tub for the about 5 months now it held air but looks like a bloated marshmallow on the top in spots. I have had to use the new pump that came with this unit and so far so good time will tell.So bottom line looks like we are stuck with a wavy topped $300.00 kiddie pool, just waiting for it doom.****Old review*****We previously owned a Coleman Saluspa. In a non-heated garage it worked perfect.But I used an air compressor to blow it up as I could not reach the valve with the filler hose and attach it to the pump.  And overnight the beams inside blew out as I put too much air in it. My bad, so thus is why I purchased this model. I wasn't going to spend another $400 bucks. Though well I'll save some money buy this one cant be that different.Big mistake, as a former owner of the 77" x 28" Coleman Saluspa all I can say is this was a huge mistake. Great design flaw and why you will not be able to use this at all in colder weather. As you will be constantly loosing heat to the exposed tube. The larger model has the tube built into the side wall. I did not run the tube and left the cap on the inlet. You will not be able to do this as I still have my old pump. You can cap the pump inlet but will need to buy a cap. But if you run the hose buy some pipe insulation foam to keep the heat in the tube.3- Just doesn't seam to fill as tight as the bigger model. Looks cheap and flimsy once filled and the security top cover  is not snug like the bigger model and sits loose around the edge. Almost looks like a kiddie pool really when filled shinny and cheap looking. Plus you get no gauge to tell you it is full. Just a filler tube. So you run it for awhile and it just stops filling. Again it looks under filled and cheap.4- No ground cover pad included? Nothing no tarp no bubble pad? The bigger model comes at least with a bubble pad. Buy some foam to put under it and a tarp.5- This will hold two people tops. I am 215 lbs and the wife is 130. If our ten year old comes in we are right on top of each other. So good for one or two comfortably. Any more or if you are bigger buy the next size up.Bottom line spend the extra $100 and buy the 77" x 28" model. Why is this important just read the reviews on pump issues and you will see why.Also it is still hot water and bubble jets so yes it is relaxing.On the pump I have this new one as a backup and I am using my older pump from my first hot tub as all the connections are the same.

author: Victor
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on December 27, 2019
review_content: Fantastic little hot tub. It says 4 person, but really I think its too small for more than 2 people less you're all really friendly!Keep in mind as you read this, that I had to sell my full sized hot tub during a divorce and moved into a rental. I missed my tub terribly and wanted a good alternative. This was the perfect solution!!First off, assembly was a snap. Using the blower as the inflator was a genius touch making it simple to blow up. Once blown up, it can be moved around empty really easily. Its just a mini version of an intex pool, made of the same great materials and bromine safe.The heater runs on 110 house voltage so it must be expected that it is slow to heat water. Compared to a big tub. No worries. Set the heater to 104 and give it a day or so and your ready to go. Make it go faster by emptying your hot water tank into it. Few times! Or, learn to be patient!The top is really important and must be kept properly inflated. When not being used, the top must be kept on to keep the heat in. We have used it for up to two hour in sub freezing temps and only lost 4 degrees, but your mileage may vary. So far its had no problem keeping 102-104 down into the teens outside and my electric bill has gone up $12. Seriously, twelve bucks.The bottom is padded and quite comfy to sit on. My shoulders are under water when seated on my butt. They offer a drunk holder and a pillow for this little gem, I recommend them both.The blower motor must have been updated because its not noisy at all. In fact I cant hear it over the AMPLE bubbles it makes!Overall, this was a fantastic buy! Having a hot tub when I thought I was going to be without was great. The performance of this little thing is even better than I could have possibly hoped for.Recommend? Heck yes!!

review_content: I thought long and hard before I bought this.  I live in the Caribbean so with added freight and duty charges this cost me about $600.  I couldn't afford to have it not work.  I have had it for about a month now and I love it.  I am using it to cool off, so I have not used the heating feature and probably never will. author: Jucribru
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on October 29, 2018
review_content: This is my 2nd inflatable tub, the 1st being the green Coleman Saluspa (which is really a rebranded Bestway).  The pumps that come with both are almost identical (except one major difference which I'll explain later) so my review will be mostly based on comparing the two tubs themselves (the inflatable part).  Because I started with the more robust tub I will admit I prefer it by far, so I have rated this one based on what it is supposed to be on it's own merit and value in comparison with the Coleman (that is only about $25 more).The Coleman tub is listed as 2" taller and 6" wider than this "Miami" model.  Long story short, when sitting in the Coleman with robust textured walls that you can put your full body weight on (sitting on the side wall without pushing it down enough to spill water), I felt like I was sitting in a legit grownup hot tub.  This Miami one's walls are thinner (far less forgiving of being leaned on & def wouldn't sit on), and the plastic is also thinner; it's made of a slick pool-float style plastic.  The tub is noticeably smaller both just observing the physical size and in roominess when inside of it.  In the Miami I almost felt like I was sitting in an over-sized Kiddie Pool.  For a single on a budget the Miami might be fine just to have some way to get a soak, but if you want something that can stand up to rambunctious kids or guests- spring for that extra $25.These tubs provide massage by way of a pump pushing air through a ring of plastic with holes in it that goes around the bottom inside of the tub; it is certainly louder than a traditional hot tub with water jets (the sound of the bubbles breaking at the top of the water is pretty loud- it's not the pump's fault) but the trade off is a more intense massage than you get with water jets.  However, the other disappointing thing about the Miami tub is that the "bubble ring" that goes around the bottom inside of the tub doesn't go all the way around, so there's a dead zone around the pump intakes where there is less bubble action and you have to consider that when choosing where to place the filter- unfortunately for me I had no choice but to put it right where I'm inclined to hang out most of the time so it was nearly a deal breaker right there.  The Coleman's "bubble ring" is 360'.*Technically* the pump that comes with the Miami is not compatible with the Coleman because of the way the intakes are.  Both tubs have two intakes inside the tub that pull in untreated water to the filter, but the Coleman's hoses are built into the sidewalls and merge down into one port that you screw from the tub into the pump body.  The Miami's pump looks exactly the same (the egg part that sits outside of the tub) except since the Miami's walls are too thin to accommodate the hoses, there's a secondary hose coming off the connection (on the pump side) that runs over to the second intake in the tub around the *outside* of the tub.  Although it's not supported, I was able to use the Miami's pump with my Coleman tub by capping off that second intake (on the pump side) and making sure it was pulling in enough water through the one remaining one as to not cause any issues with the pump/heater/sensors.  Hooked up that way it works just like the original green Coleman pump did so far but I'm sure using this way voids any warranty I might've enjoyed.In short since this one is only $25 or so cheaper than the larger Bestways (and the Coleman branded Bestway), I'd have expected the tub to be of the same quality as the Coleman and just be a bit smaller... but it's very disappointing in that regard.  For the quality of the Miami tub, I would've expected to pay at *least* $50 less than I paid for the Coleman.  I'll keep it in case my Coleman tub becomes irreparable, but in the meantime I'm happy to have a pump back for my big Green Hot Tubbing Machine.Side Note:  If you've never owned a hot tub, remember you *must* keep the cover on it when not in use for the tub to retain heat even with the heater on.  These "egg" style pump/filter/heater combos are notorious for burning out early too but since you're not paying for a robust heater/pump I don't feel like that's a reason to bash the purchase... the flimsy tub is though.
title: Much Less Robust Than the Coleman

author: Crazylabrat
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on July 1, 2019
review_content: This is my 2nd Miami spa!  The first one lasted me 3 summers, this would've been the 4th.  I went to put it up, and the heater/pump still worked, but there was a small hole I couldn't find in the tub part.I live in Michigan and use the spa non-stop from May to Oct.  Here are some tips to get it to last for you:1. Put foam mats under the tub.  This will help the tub last longer and give you a little cushion to sit on.  I used camping mats.2. Only run the heater/pump non-stop until you get it hot.  After that utilize the timer function.  More on that later.3. Run the filters through the dishwasher at least once a week.  One set will last you all summer.4. To keep it clean, use a foot bath/wash, before entering the tub.  Get a small spa size skimmer for the floaties.  To get sand and stuff that has sunk to the bottom, I use a super soaker, suck up the bottom dwellers, then I'll run it thru the skimmer, putting the hot water back in the spa, and catching the sand and stuff in the skimmer net.5. Always keep the top on when not in use.  This keeps it clean and keeps it hot.Here is how I use the timer:There is a button that has 2 timers on it.  When you push it once, the one that looks like a stopwatch will blink first, that is how long you want your heater/pump to run for, push the arrow keys to how many hours you want it running.  Push the button again and the one that looks like a clock is in how many hours you want your heater/pump to turn on.This is what I do after I go in the spa at night, I shut down the heater and set the timer to turn the heater on in 8 hrs, to heat for 2 hrs.  That way it'll be ready and hot for me in the morning before work.  After I get out in the morning, I set the timer to turn the heater on in hrs, to heat for 2 hrs, that way it'll be ready for me when I get home from work.  I might leave it on all evening if we're going from the pool to the spa, and back again.  This way, you're not eating up energy just keeping it hot when it doesn't have to be.When warm out, 60-90 degrees, I only pre-warm it for 2 hrs max, in colder weather, 40-60 degrees I'll pre-warm for 3-4 hrs.You can't ask for much more at this price point.  If I buy a new one every 3 years, that's a steal.
title: Love this! On my 2nd one.

author: Q
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on December 8, 2018
review_content: I bought 2 of these. Got one all setup and filled with water. Nothing but E02 codes. The inside caps are removed. Pressing the heat or pump button causes an immediate EO2 code and it shuts down and beeps. Looks like I have a defective pump. Save hours of time and hundreds of dollars and buy from a company that has better quality control. I'll be returning both of these.

author: BluesViews
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on June 2, 2020
review_content: This hot tub is perfect for one. It’s ok for 2 if you’re cosy, but the thing that’s great about this hot tub is you will quickly decide it’s really all yours and no one else should be allowed near it! Haha. Well - good luck with that, but if you are envisioning it being a roomy 2 person one I’d look at the next size up. If you are happy to be cosy and snug and are on a budget then it’s great. It was fairly easy to assemble. The instructions are for a range of models so you have to use a little common sense. Once up, mine took 16hrs to reach 104 in California. It was not particularly hot weather. Chlorine tablets are the 1” variety and it doesn’t come with any so order those in advance and pop 2 in the dispenser every couple of days. A pack of test strips will be handy too. The filters do pick up dirt quickly but you can hose them off easily.I suspect you can get at least a month or 6 weeks out of a pair - this is going to depend on how much you use your hot tub.You are going to use it a lot I reckon 😎Loving this buy!
title: A really fun and relaxing hot tub that’s better than you hope it will be!

author: Isla
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on June 5, 2020
review_content: What I like about this hot tub is that it comes with everything you need except chemicals. The cover does a great job of keeping dirt and debris out and it clips on so no blowing off, the clips have an extra safety feature on them making it harder for little kids to unlatch them. The bottom has a soft foam-like cushion padding on bottom. The buttons are easy to use and have a lock feature. It comes with 2 filters.What I don’t like about this hot tub is that it does take some time to warm up and it quickly drops a couple degrees when the cover is off. The instructions that came with it are horrible. It is a sheet of pictures that are not labeled making it confusing and frustrating.  It would have been easy to set up if the directions were clear. Even though the kit came with some type of chemical container (which wasn’t labeled on directions either) there was no clear directions on what to use or how to use it.It’s definitely not a standard hot tub like one at a hotel but for the price and low maintenance my family likes it.
title: Cozy little tub with bubbles

author: Grayhawk1
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on March 16, 2021
review_content: This is a great "personal size" hot tub for two adults.  It looks nice, was easy to inflate and hook up the heater/pump, and it was easy to maintain.  HOWEVER - after setup I noticed it was losing inflation and in a period of 3-4 days the sidewalls became very 'soft.'  At first, I thought this might be the natural initial expansion and contraction of the liner - so I re-filled it to maximum inflation - and hoped the issue was resolved.  NOT!  It continued to lose air and I repeated the re-inflation process 3 additional times until I gave up.  I gave it a low rating not because of the product itself, but rather there is no phone contact/support available from the manufacturer and/or distributor so you can't speak with anyone.  Their website indicates they will call you ... but that didn't happen.  Sent a second request for a callback - same result ... crickets!  Very disappointed in the customer service! The issue could have been simply resolved with a replacement liner.  Instead, Amazon was great as ever and I will be returning the defective tub and receive a replacement hot tub with all the necessary parts.
title: Great product - lousy customer service!

author: Cindy C.
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on September 24, 2019
review_content: OMG i was so excited to buy this inflatable hot tub and with the Coleman name and the positive reviews i decided to buy it. I enjoyed it very much up until the pump started leaking water about 6 months into it. It took sometime to acquire information on how to contact Bestway because the 800 number for Bestway gives you the run around.  When we finally got the second pump which Bestway sent out at no additional cost we were happy with the tub ! yay..... However, my happiness with this tub was not that long. only 2 months after receiving the new pump the pump had some serious electrical problems and blew and melted the microchip board inside the pump. GOOD GRIEF..Not only did the pump mess up again but the tub itself is misshaped by the weather. This tub is a lot of headache and not happy with the customer service with Best Way. Hopefully i can get a full refund or get a replacement if the company won't give me a refund. On a positive note I did enjoy it when it worked and it was easy to maintain.

author: kim clabough
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on January 16, 2017
review_content: Oh my!  I can't have a full size hot tub where I live.  I was a little apprehensive about purchasing this item.  I have no regrets at all!  It is wonderful to sit in and relax at night.  I did purchase some pipe insulation to put around the water feed line going to the pump, that seemed to help the heating process.  The only caution that I can offer is that it says four adults can fit in it....I guess if the are all super tiny that would work.  It is perfect for TWO adults comfortable.
title: Small but awesome

author: Jimmy
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on June 9, 2018
review_content: It only lasted one season. Leaking air now. The material is too thin.
title: One Star

author: Frank Madrigal
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on January 1, 2020
review_content: I want to return this product. My wife and I had it for a year before the heating element went out on the unit. I followed all the cleaning requirements and kept a tight schedule and when filters were replaced and what chemicals to best use.  I even had the whole unit in the garage where it was kept away from the outdoor elements.  Just before we had it for a full year the unit would error out and shut off.  After some research its because the heating unit would mal function and stop working causing the whole unit to error out.  Very disappointing and would like to get my money back on this one.

author: Maysen MacLamroc
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on November 16, 2019
review_content: I bought this product in March of 2019. Installation took about an hour total. 15 mins to assemble and 30-45 mins to fill up with water. It started heating around 6PM and was 104 degrees by 7AM the next morning. It heats up about 2 degrees an hour. This product has worked great for several months. It is now winter In NC and it is still going strong even when it gets down to 19 degrees outside. Stays hot while in use with jets for about an hour during the summer and 30 minutes during the winter.I use it every morning and night. This product is well worth the cheap price tag.I’ve had a couple trial and error problems with keeping it inflated and keeping it from leaking but as long as you do regular maintenance it works great and won’t leak or deflate.Would certainly recommend this to anyone looking for a hot tub that doesn’t want to invest thousands. This is a quick cheap alternative that works amazing.
title: Amazing product as long as you do regular maintenance

author: Sally Gorman
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on December 23, 2020
review_content: The directions are horrible like everyone has said. If youre somewhat smart, you'll figure it out. Super easy to blow up. Some attachments are questionable as to where they go. The white saucer piece that looks like it's supposed to go in the bottom of the tub, it goes into the cover to hold it atop the water. We were a little confused with that. If you plan on having more than 2 people in the tub, fill to the MIN line. Our kids were all over it like it was a pool and we were spilling it all over our floor (we did it in our house downstairs as we have a split level and it gets too cold here for outside.This spa pumps some bubbles! We were not expecting it to be so powerful! It is VERY to the actual thing you see in hotels and such. My husband is a hot tub snob and he was pleasantly surprised with the power of this hot tub. It's great for the cold winter months here in Boston for the time being until we get a permanent one for outside.I would definitely recommend this!
title: Great alternative to a professional hot tub

author: Jinyfer
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on June 5, 2020
review_content: This is an incredible little hot tub. I've had it for almost 6 months. We use it on average every other day. I've changed the filters once and really haven't used much bromide. I'm still amazed. One thing I don't get is why the price has gone up soo much. I paid $250. and now they seem hard to find and twice + the price.  All in all - I'm very pleased with my little hot tub. ******UPDATE - My GFC keeps tripping for no apparent reason. I've had the tub for 8 months and it was great until now.  I can't keep the pump/heater running.  I contracted Bestway Corp., the manufacturer, but they have not responded to my inquiry.
title: I'm still shocked - and then the shoe dropped

author: LuvzPrime
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on April 20, 2021
review_content: The temperature gets cold fast as soon as you take off the cover and turn on the bubbles. What a disappointment.:(  It seems very sturdy and looks great but getting ready to try it for the first time last night we soon realized we couldn't if we didn't want to freeze.The temps outside were chilly but not freezing at 65 and a beautiful night. The thermostat said 104 and it felt great so we took the cover off and turned on the bubbles. We didn't get in yet because in 15mins it had dropped to 99 degrees and then 97 within 30 mins. That is cold to your body in case you don't know that.  How sad. I could return it. I have time still to do that but how sad to lose 300+ gallons of water. Trying to fit this thing back in the box will be impossible I'm sure, and I've spent $70 on hot tub chemicals. When people say that the temps drop after you turn the bubbles on or even just take off the lid, they are telling the truth.The bubbles blow cool air out so no wonder it gets cold. So, I am searching like crazy to see if there's any kind of heater we can add to this thing while it's in use. A 300 gallon aquarium I had once had a water heater that I could stick my hands in it while it was working, could something like that maybe heat this 300 gallons of water without electrocuting people? I want to invite 2 friends over to sit in it but now I feel kind of embarrassed about it. We'll get in and it will feel good but after 10 mins we'll have to get out bc it's chilly.Anyway, I am not sure if there's anyway anyone that can give me info on a heater but I'd love to try it. Otherwise this will just be a mini pool to cool off in this hot summer but not actually a hot tub in the cool weather.
title: Would be great & 5 stars but....

author: Stan Anderton
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on July 26, 2018
review_content: Years ago I bought a hot tub for use at our new country home.  It was heavy, expensive, and cost another $500 plus for electrical and other prep needs.  I loved it, and used it often.  Not that many years later it was outdated, faded, and not working as well.  After about six years it had lived its life.  It was a lot of work removing it and hauling it  off.I had wanted another hot tub, but the cost kept me from doing it.  My wife saw this inflatable hot tub on Amazon, and we decided to give it a shot.  WOW!  Yes, the instructions were pretty pathetic in my humble opinion. They say a picture is worth a thousand words, but I think that is for a REAL picture, and a picture combined with the proper words are priceless.  Just saying.  Anyway, it didn't take too long to get it all figured out and an hour or so after taking the box to the back patio it was filling with water.  A few hours later, my wife and I hopped in and were so pleased with our purchase.  If you figure the cost of the least expensive fiberglass tub at around $3000, you could buy a new one of these each year and still come out ahead.  I expect this to last a few years if taken care of.  We shall see, but for now I am elated at our bargain.  I definitely would recommend this to my friends and family.  Now, it shows four people in the picture.  NOT!  Not unless they are small people, but it is great for my wife and I and MAYBE one of our younger grandchildren.
title: A Great purchase - for two people

author: Kim
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on January 3, 2021
review_content: I was unsure about buying this hot tub. I am a single mom and I was worried I wouldn’t be able to put it together. It only took my daughter and I about an hour to set it up. It was a lot easier than I expected! The manual it comes with is not well written. I found the online set up videos from you-tube much easier to follow when I was setting it up. It took about 24 hrs to get to 104 degrees. The first time I stepped in I knew I made the right decision! I love it. So does my daughter. I only have a few complaints. The heater and bubbles don’t stay on at the same time. When the bubbles are on the heater unit sounds like a shop vac, but once you are inside the tub the bubbles drown out that noise.  The water temperature only goes down about 4-5 degrees depending on how long you stay in. It stay warm for a long time. I also enjoy sitting in it without the bubbles on! Make sure you put the inflatable top inside the cover, it fits inside the cover, they are not two separate pieces. A good seal will keep the water warm. I leave the heater on all the time. I saw a video that recommended that keeping the heater on will save money in the long run...we will see what my utility bill looks like. This tub is well worth it during this difficult pandemic. It makes me feel like I am escaping all of this stress. You won’t be sorry you bought this soothing tub!
title: Treat yourself to a relaxing warm hot tub for a great price!!

author: Stormtech
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on May 8, 2019
review_content: I had a Coleman Lay-Z-Spa for 5 years almost trouble free. When that was done, I ordered this Miami-Spa from Bestway because it looked identical and I liked the color better. The first thing I noticed was the thickness of the tub plastic material. The Bestway was thin like a beach ball, compared to the Coleman which was more like an inflatable life raft. I used it for a month then drained it to go on vacation. When I returned 2 months later, it would not start up. Went to their website for customer support entered my contact info they said they would return a call within 2 days. It’s been 2 weeks now and no call back. I’m ready to set it on fire. Bad, Bad, Bad Customer Service and Support
title: Bad Construction, Bad Customer Support.  Had a Coleman, it was much better

author: P. Tromp
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on May 2, 2017
review_content: Love the concept but loses a star for messy, expensive filters and another for poor seam welds. I plumbed in a Penn plax 1200 aquarium filter which increases flow and needs cleaning only once a month. The filter needs to be off when the heater is started or it has a fault which requires a good thump on the heater to reset. The seams inside the tub will start to fail after about a year. Careful patching with Tear-aid type B and a heat gun will make a good repair, but requires draining the water to be able to do a good job. I think they are just a little sloppy when they weld the seams at the Chinese factory.As one user has recommended, initial heating with a propane gas water heater and a good submersible pump can give you full temps in a matter of hours after filling with a garden hose.I have found the Tear-aid B type unable to take the temperature/water, and pulls away over time. Am trying Tenacious Tape Flex patches on some 1/2" tears. Will praise them if they work over time. The manufacturer should be ashamed that they show tub replacements as always "out of stock" and don't answer repeated queries about when they can supply. Must be that they want you to buy a whole new set!! Update, Tenacious Tape patches are holding nicely despite water and heat. You should order some with the tub!
title: good if you modify the filtration and be ready to patch seams

author: J.D.M
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on February 12, 2021
review_content: I have used this twice and it has exceeded my expectations. Time will tell but as for right now, this is the best purchase that I have made on Amazon. I have it set up in my garage right now because it is winter and I wanted to get in it as soon as possible. I will move it to the deck in the spring.  I filled it with water from an outside faucet, I think the water temp was in the 50's and I set the spa heater to 100. It averaged about 2 degrees per hour.  I will have to do some research on what chemicals to use and performing the required maintenance. Keep in mind that those will be a separate purchase, as this comes with none and very little info about them. Overall, I highly recommend this item. Also, when you are airing it up (and the cover too) do not hold your hand over the opening in the hose, it is designed that way so that you don't over inflate. I hope something that I have said here helps you in some way. God bless 😊
title: Very easy to set up.

author: D. Meador
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on April 12, 2019
review_content: This is my second inflatable spa.  The first one was a green Coleman.  I preferred it to this black Saluspa because 1) it didn't have the air hose on the side and 2) had a better drain with a tube going to the outside edge of the spa.  My first spa got heavy use and the vinyl finally wore out after about three years.  I could have made it last longer but for the price I was fine with completely replacing it.  The pump was going just fine even after all that use.  So I got this one and after six months the pump started to get loud.  I called Bestway and within days had a new pump.  We'll see how this one lasts.  Overall I'm very happy with these inflatable spas.  We live in a moderate climate: not Minneapolis, but not Phoenix.  During the winter months (average lows in the 20's) I'll run it 10-12 hours to get it to approximately 103 degrees.  In the summer (average highs in the mid 90's), I'll run it just an hour or two to make approximately 99 degrees.  Electricity and water are cheaper here so it's use doesn't much effect my utility bill.  I don't worry too much about chemicals and cleanliness: I usually just dump the water out every so often.  It's easy to do.
title: Bestway customer service has been excellent, in my experience

author: Paul E.
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on July 1, 2020
review_content: Bought this on a whim as I don't really want a permanent hot tub, but wanted something for the winter months and this did the trick.  We live in SC where we get below freezing but seldom for a long period, typically just over night on dozen or so nights.  We put the unit outside for the whole winter and had no problems.  If the pump/heater was left on it would keep the 104 temp regardless of the weather.  We used it 2-3 times a week.  It's not a real hot tub with jets massaging your back, but it is a nice relaxing soak.Best part was in May when the weather started to heat up I was able to take the unit down and store it.  After deflating it and folding it up, it was not the size that it originally was.  But I took an XXL vacuum storage back, and used that to compact (suck the air out), and it became a managable cube.  Actually fit it back into the original box with the pump for summer storage.Hopefully when I pull it out in October, it will be like new and everything will work.
title: Overall worth the money.

author: Rissy
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on April 24, 2016
review_content: I have had the Miami hot tub for about 5 months now. I really like it a lot, for the most part. It's very relaxing, especially under the stars.The pros: Very durable. My German Shepard has jumped on it a few times while it was covered and there was no impact or damage, nor did it collapse or even lose air.The bubbles are very strong. I thought they were comparable to the jets of a hot tub. It also is a nice soaking tub.Very low maintenance. I use non-chlorine products 2 to 3 times a week and change the filters every couple of weeks depending on use.I like that it has no seats because it's more comfortable to keep your legs stretched out and the bottom of it has a nice comfy cushion.The temperature of 104 is sufficient for most of the year but I live in a very warm climate.The cons:  It was too cold to use it in the winter once it got below 40 degrees, since the heater doesn't stay on while the bubbles are on. The water would lose it's temperature after about 20 min and drop to around 97-100. author: Stogie
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on March 4, 2016
review_content: I am a 20 year spa user. I had to leave my real spa when I moved from NC to CO. My place here has a rooftop deck. I wanted a spa but not the expense of another "real" spa and a crane to get it up there. I had some good luck with an inflatable Intex Spa at our beach house in NC, so I decided to try one here. I got the Bestway Lay-Z-Spa because it is slightly smaller and fits my space. It set up easily Friday morning and it was hot by the next day. The directions say not to use it under 40 degrees, but it has held up well to Colorado weather in the two weeks I have had it. I like to use it in the morning. One morning the outside temperature was 19 degrees and the spa was at 103. The thermostat is a little temperamental. I set it at 102 but it often heats to 103 or 104. The bubbles will cool it down pretty fast. Without running the bubbles it holds a comfortable temperature for 30 minutes to an hour depending on ambient temperature. I added pipe insulation to the clear filter return tube that runs outside the spa. That is key in below 40 degree temperatures. The heater will shut itself off if you don't use it for 3 days, which is not ideal because I travel and like it to be hot. It does have a timer feature so the morning I leave I can set the heater to come on in 48 hours and run for 24 hours, so the water doesn't get so cold before I get home. For the money paid for this it has been well worth it. It is not going to give you a hydro massage but it works well and keeps the water hot. review_content: I've had this tub for 14 months and I have had no problems.It was easy to assemble, and it has been reliable and easy to deal with.Energy cost is about $100/month (in Berkeley where it never reaches freezing temperatures).Minor complaints:* The 'feature' so many complain about, where it turns itself off after 3 days if not touched, is definitely super annoying (since there is no way to change this setting).* If the power to the tub is interrupted you have to manually restart the heater/pump unit.* It is a pain to empty because of how they set up the drain hole. review_content: Okay - here it is, I spent SO MUCH time researching and debating the question of whether or not to set this up in New England in the middle of winter, so hopefully this review will be helpful to others. The cover has stayed inflated, the tub itself remains sturdy after almost every day use, for the past two months. Definitely worth the buy!
title: Definitely recommend it

author: D. Obryen
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on April 8, 2020
review_content: I got this hot tub back in 2018. I live in flordia and It was great when I first got it. Started to get tired and I neglected for over two years. Just didnt have the time to use it nor clean it anymore. Well today I went out there and cleaned it took awhile it was nasty.So after two years just sitting out in my backyard it pretty much still looks pretty good. After the cleaning of course. Now my first thing to check was the pump/heater. I plugged it in and it came on and I mean everything worked. The bubbles the filters and the heat all work very good. Very impressed I told my self. author: Peggy Faranda
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on August 10, 2020
review_content: No real assembly instructions but I found a YouTube video that helped.  Bought this on a lightning deal in January and didn’t set it up til July but for the price it’s been really impressive.  We use it all the time now, both to relax in at its warmest temp, which is plenty hot, and to cool down in on a hot day.  Didn’t expect much from the jets but they really do help in the relaxation process.  Only thing we did wrong was not filtering the water that we drew straight from our hose at the spigot which pulls directly from our well. title: Impressive little hot tub

author: snody
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on October 30, 2016
review_content: Bought one of these a few years back for my wife as a birthday gift. It had popped at the end of the prior season and I had to fix a leak, which I did with a hot glue gun and we were back in action. This little hot tub compared to the cost of a conventional one is unbelievable(just to wire in a conventional hot tub would have paid all costs incurred for the whole three years ive had it..including purchase cost). Set up is easy. Size is perfect for two. If you don't use it all year long it is easy to store until the following season. It involves alone time in hot water with my wife for less than $ 400....... some of the best money Ive EVER spent.Update 2/18 /17Had to retire the original and buy the new model. The old one would not hold air any longer. The new version has a few updated features and is a little bit different dimensions. I still recommend  this as one of the best purchases someone can make.  Adam S.
title: It works good enough for the first two years that I would ...

author: Spike
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on May 6, 2021
review_content: The spa does have a padded bottom (approx 1").  It does not come with the "egg" shaped heater, but has the rectangular one with flip up control panel. Apparently since the 2018 models, the heater now continues to run with the bubble function on. Control unit runs with a slight hum, and cannot be heard with bubbles on. title: Things not in the product description.

author: Peng V.
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on May 25, 2021
review_content: The product and customer service is just as poor quality as the part. author: Amazon Customer
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on May 28, 2020
review_content: This lasted about 6 months.I've bought a couple of these and I have to replace them about every 6 months or so.What happens is they develop a leak and there is no way to fix the leak because it is where there is a weakness in the design. Because of that it leaks and we have to throw away the entire thing. It feels like a huge waste for such a small problem.
title: I wish they were more easily repaired

author: L
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on April 27, 2016
review_content: Ok, so this would be my second layzspa. They are all awesome, and I highly recommend them. The first one I got was the Coleman layzspa, and comparing the Coleman and the Miami, I would say there seems to be more reinforcement in the walls of the Coleman one. It is quite a bit more sturdy. That's not to say the Miami isn't great, it is. So great, we bought one as a gift for an employee and his wife. They are filling it now. I have no doubt they will love it.I think the Coleman and the Palm Springs may be a closer comparison, and when I buy a fourth one, I think I will buy the Palm Springs. I think it, like the Coleman, prolly has more water capacity, and therefore requires more reinforcement on the side walls, making it seem less like an inflatable hot tub. I would pick the palm springs over the Coleman only because of the color. Colman green is great when I'm camping, but I'll keep it on my laterns and stoves rather than a somewhat permenant fixture in my backyard. I have yet to have any kind of problems with any of my hot tubs. As with any outdoor fixture, after a while they get dirty and sun faded, and the beauty of these is that when that happens, I can just get a new one, instead of having an eyesore in my backyard. The first one I had was out in the weather for a couple of years, and always faired well. No problems with wind, heat, rain, it was always ready for us to jump in. I sold it when we moved, and bought another. These are awesome if you rent your house!
title: Just get it!!!!

author: JSP
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on May 24, 2021
review_content: Was not expecting it to be a sweet as it is. Easy no brainer set up. A day to heat and you’re living the tub life. For comparison- 2 nights at a coastal mineral tub resort will set you back $900 not inc. the cost of the drive, food, wine etc. and for your mere $600ish investment you can enjoy a soak nightly.The timer function needs to be reset daily which is bs and probably because some beancounter wanted to save pennies during manufacturing. We just turn ours off at night and then back on in the afternoon.
title: Tub Life 2021!

author: Uwish
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on March 1, 2016
review_content: I bought this as a Used - Like New spa.  It was EXACTLY as described.  Packaging had been opened and the box had some damage, HOWEVER, the inside packaging was in perfect condition and the spa had never been used and was in perfect shape. Best of all we saved $$ by buying it used. The instructions are HORRIBLE, however, with a bit of simply trying things, we were able to put it together and put it up in about 20 mins.  We put this INSIDE our house in a add on room that has french doors to separate it from the main living areas.  We live in an extremely dry climate so the humidity is not an issue for us, but I couldn't imagine it inside anywhere but the desert without good ventilation.  Buy an extra set of filters right away, it says to wash them with each use but we bought these floating sponge bugs that help keep the water clear, so we actually change the filters once a week.  We use bromine with it and we have no kids at home so it is just adults using it about every other day.  It is perfect temp - 104 not so hot you feel drained when you get out and the bubble ring at the bottom of it bubbles hard enough that it feels like a percussion massage on your entire back, without hurting, so it doesn't matter that it doesn't have individual jets.  This does come with a velcro down cover, two filters and a chemical float, however it does not come with any chemicals and it does not have the padded underlayer that the next size up spa (or the coleman lazysport spa) does.  The floor is padded with just the air that inflates it and we have it sitting on a hard tile floor and it is comfortable.
title: Perfect low cost spa

author: Lestan
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on July 27, 2018
review_content: Heard about an inflatable hot tub. Thought it had to be an infomercial or some gimmick. Turns out, this baby is worth every expletive dollar. Time tested, it pays for itself with pleasure. Few items are you ever actually proud of buying. This is one.I purchased this for my family after finishing a college degree that really exhausted us to the limit. I wanted something that was relaxing and rewarding for all of us. I didn't have a lot of cash after being buried in student debt, barely a 3 day vacation saved, and I wanted something that would last. Toys and trips, everything we buy these days seems to get forgotten as we find new interests. Our house had a giant retractable awning that also works particularly good over this tub.So I researched, talked it over with the wife, and ordered it. This thing was easy to unpack and get working. Compared to our 30" deep Intex pool it was a huge relief. Took a while to heat up but that was expected. My only complaint, and really my only one, is that somewhere in the tub styrofoam was left when it was filled. I did not have any issues getting it unpacked so am not sure where it came from. Had weeks of little particles floating around, but it is no longer an issue at all.The heat warm off cycle is a bit tricky to get at first, if you won't take anything less than 104 degrees, which it'll easily max out at (and is as hot as I would ever want) you've got to check on it like a pet. Unlock the panel, bump up the temp, etc. I understand this is important because there are days I go without wanting to use it.Keeping it clean is a cinch and quite easy once you've done it a few times. My recommendation is skip the ridiculous cleaning tools and pick up a $1 pool squirting toy thing. I got one from our Dollar store during summer. It does a fine job picking up gravel and other particles. It also doubles as a weapon.Have not yet packed it away for the season, but I imagine it will not be very difficult with the drainage plug. I will be sad that day.So.... Worth it? Yup.
title: Before this hot tub, I could not imagine more value for my money

author: EMILY BENNETT
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on June 27, 2019
review_content: The only problem I have is that the heater will stop working randomly. I'll go outside to get in the hot tub and the water temp will be at 78° because the pump shuts off. This happens quite frequently. Not a big deal if you don't use it every day, and you can turn it back on and wait until tomorrow to get in, but if you're a daily user, this might be a problem.I haven't had any problems with the sturdiness, no punctures or leaks. The cover works well to keep dirt out of the water. Animals leave it alone (we were worried about squirrels and birds tearing it). Other than the pump/heater failing, this is a good product.

date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on October 5, 2020
review_content: I was super excited to receive this . Easy to set up. I cannot see how 4 people can fit, but possibly 2. title: Error message 02 if I try to heat the pool, and it shuts down.

author: Troy Davidson
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on April 17, 2018
review_content: So do yourself a favor and watch the video on putting this together on YouTube! It’s really simple and I totally over thought it. The instructions are right on the box, the insert just had a photo of each part and the part numbers for replacing needs. The pump inlfates both the hot tub and the top cover. I over inflated and had problems screwing in one of the two provided filters. The tubing from the enclosed pump screws directly to the side of the tub; there is very little slack so make sure you plan where you want everything before filling with water. I wish it heated to 106 but I like really hot water, my spouse is more comfortable when the temp is 100....so to each their own. The bubbles are surprisingly strong and sitting in front of them will bounce your shoulder blades...it feels amazing! If this last a few years it’s worth it.
title: I’m happy with this!

author: AliceLoree
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on December 31, 2015
review_content: This was our Christmas present to ourselves as we have moved out into the country and don't have a soaker tub, spa or access to one and I have chronic back issues.  This spa is absolutely amazing.  When we sit in it, the water covers my shoulders with wonderful warmth. The bubbles are stronger than I expected - they aren't hard core jets but they are more than adequate. We started with this model as a Black Friday purchase since we'd never seen a spa of this portable style "live" so we wanted to not spend too much in case it was a bust.  My husband had it assembled and filling with water within 15 minutes - super simple to assemble. It is very light to carry without water - pretty much could be moved by anyone. Since we've had it, living in he northwest, it has weathered record rainfall, snow, excessive wind and now below freezing temps.  Although it isn't recommended for temperatures such as the 20's and 30's, with a bit of extra insulation it seems to be doing fine.  It doesn't look super spacious when looking at it as it's filling, However, when sitting in it, it's very roomy. Spacious for tow of us, would be fine with three and I think four would be better during hot weather when enjoying a summer evening and not needing to have complete submersion.  We are appreciate that it can use the 110 and doesn't need the 220. We have a 220 but it's not where we'd want to put the tub. I hope if you purchase this tub you enjoy it as much as we have!
title: Best Christmas present to ourselves ever!

author: Kristen Nusbaum
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on June 8, 2020
review_content: Purchased in an attempt to bring summer vacation to our home during COVID quarantine. Our three kids love having this hot tub in their backyard- us parents too!We do have a hard time understanding the controls
title: the temperature is not easily adjusted.  We will have to continue the learning process on this.The bubbles are fun and the faux tile is a crack up. We love the sturdy inflatable sides. We will hope this spa lasts a few years at least.
verified: Easy and suitable for non spa snobs.

author: Matthew Noonan
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on January 11, 2020
review_content: I bought this on a clearance sale back in 2016.  I always wanted a hot tub but the cost of installation and set up for one was just too much for something I could only use for a couple of months living up in Vermont.  This was the perfect solution.  I didn’t even know they existed.  Set up was less than 15 mins, filled it up, chlorinated and turned it on.  It takes about a day and a half to get to temp but that depends on the ambient temp changes.  I used it all the time and felt it was the best purchase of my life.  Just like any pool product you must keep up with chemical levels and cleaning, change the filters and when storing, make sure it’s fully dried out and kept sealed so that bugs don’t work their way into the channels and cause clogs.  If outdoor temp drops below 50 degrees for extended periods then store it for the season because the motor just can’t keep up with the heating.  I ended up having to give it away when I moved south because I was moving into an apartment and missed it so much I just bought a new one.  I’m sure that there are bad ones in the bunch but it’s so very much worth it over having a permanent one installed at quadruple the cost.
title: Totally worth it

author: Well Put
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on August 27, 2015
review_content: This thing is freakin' awesome. Seriously. I had an empty roof in NYC (with water/electric hookups nearby), and thought to myself, "How can I turn this empty space in to the most epic party venue.... EVER?" Let me tell you, I didn't have to look far.When I first saw this, I was really skeptical. Seriously... how good could an inflatable kiddie pool really be? Well kids, let me tell you. I was wrong. This thing kicks major butt. For starters, it's sooooo easy to set up. The bubble pump inflates the tub/cover, so you don't need your own air pump. Then, fill with water and add chemicals. Plug it in, and wait about a day for it to heat up. Get in, and have your mind COMPLETELY BLOWN!! I was worried that 104 degrees would be too low, but wow, it feels great. Soaking outside in hot water after a hard workout is amazing.It's also super portable. I was going home for a family get-together, and simply drained out all the water and threw it in the back of my compact car. It fit so easily with no hassle, along with all my other luggage. I got to the party, set it up, and it was a HUGE hit. Everybody loved it and wanted to get one of their own. The kids especially loved it, as they were constantly jumping in and out. That also speaks for it's durability.The only drawback is the maintenance. You have to be aware of the chemical levels, and clean the filters every day. Other than that, it's one of the best purchases I've made on Amazon. Period. Do yourself a favor if you're on the fence, and just buy it. I promise you won't look back.
title: Best. Purchase. EVER!

author: Bru22
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on March 22, 2020
review_content: I am writing this from the hot tub. This thing is great. I setup it up during the winter months, took 3 days to come up to temp with the outside temp in the 40s during the day, 30s at night. Holds it’s temperature really well. author: Chris Ellsworth
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on March 3, 2021
review_content: Delivered on time and in good shape. Assembly instructions are junk. I had water going into it within an hour. author: Amazon Customer

review_content: We don't like the preprogrammed timer that shuts the heater off about every 3 days! When first reading the reviews the  4 out of 5 stars seemed like a good choice for the money. Didn't see the heater issue in the main reviews. That why I'm putting it out there. We've been using it for about a month now and noticed that we have to turn the heater on about every 3rd day. So if you want to babysit your hot tub all the time it's a good choice. Set up was easy thoughUpdate...after using for 4 months, got an E02 error. Tried to get a hold of company 🤣🤣 which is a joke!! They make it so hard that you give up out of frustration! This hot tub is nothing but garbage! Don't make the same mistake add I did!
title: Don't make this purchase....you'll regret it!!!

author: russell
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on December 17, 2015
review_content: So Ten days since I received the product.  It sets up just as easily as the description say it will. It took about 3 minutes to inflate the tube with the built in compressor and then another 90 secs or so to inflate the inflatable part of the two piece cover. Then attaching the pump to the side of the tub was quick (Hint: start with the "A" connection it will make the others line up and seat easier).  Then Fill With Water.  It’s only a couple hundred gallons so that won’t take long with your standard hose connection.  I think this whole process took about 30 minutes.  I Tested for Chlorine at this point to which my city has very little so I add some (Hint: Use Chlorine or Bromine that is specifically compounded for Low Volume Bodies of water or Spas). Then I Started the Heater and Filter Pump set it to 104F.  The Rating on the pump is accurate for an environment that doesn't fall below about 50F.  I do see about a 2 degree/hour Rise when I turn on the pump in the morning.  I must admit that I cheated in the initial heating process by removing pots of water from the pool boiling and returning. I was able to gain out 5 degrees per hour by boiling about 4 pot and hour.  I continued off and one till the pool was at about 100F and letting the pool get to the final number.  The Timer Feature is great and allows for small amounts of energy savings but running the tub full time doesn’t cost that much.  I set mine to heat form 14 hours after I get out and on a delay of 10 hours.  That wording will make more sense after you read the manual for the spa.  As of yet I have had no inflation issues with the spa but transfers from hot to cooler and back will cause anything to deflate.  It stays at temperature for at least 30 min when the ambient temp is over 40F.  All in all this is spa cost 10% of a permanent Spa that also has to be professionally installed and still runs at high wattage.  Meaning that if this spa last more than one year then its ROI is indeed positive.
title: Worth it. . . so far and looking good

author: Peter
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on February 3, 2020
review_content: Since MN winter is too cold for this, we put it in our basement. I was worried about sturdiness- if it leaked at all, it would be a disaster. Turns out it’s very well made! Extremely sturdy. I have no more fear. The water got up to temperature in about 8 hours. The bubbles are stronger than I thought as well.It was tricky to put together the first time because the directions aren’t great, and there are extra parts you don’t need. But once you get it, it is easy the next time. We got a submersible pump which makes it fast and easy to empty the water and not worry about any water on the floor!I am so glad we made this purchase. When it’s warmer outside, we plan to move it to our patio. For now, it’s wonderful to have in the privacy of our home and near our shower!
title: Better than expected

author: TurtlePhreak
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on April 28, 2021
review_content: Everyone needs this hot tub! Stop searching and just buy the darn thing. It is FANTASTIC!  5 min to set it up and inflate it. The water heated from 68 deg F to 104 in less than 10 hours. (Average outside temp here ranges between 42-60F daily.) The bubbles run 30min, and temp decreases to 100F by end of cycle. They bubbles have force and actually masssage your whole back and neck, even your feet. 2 people fit easily, but you will touch.Cons: The pump does has a low-level hum, and sounds like a shop-vac with a high pitched whine when the bubbles are turned on. (I live in a very quiet place, so I do not use it before 9am or after 9pm.)

author: DeeR
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on April 2, 2019
review_content: I can't believe that customer support MIGHT be available within 2 business days , especially when you're trying to set up the spa.  Their video is not the answer to all situations, especially when you haven't received all the parts. author: Jacinta Mae
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on January 4, 2016
review_content: My husband and I have had this hot tub for a few weeks now and are super impressed for the price and it being a blow up hot tub. It does take awhile to heat, about 24 hours. We did notice it heats twice as fast if you put the cover on it though. The temp has been consistently staying 100 to 104 degrees which is great. author: Wayne Marsonette
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on January 3, 2020
review_content: The tub is sturdy and easy to assemble. That being said we have used the tub for a month and the filters could be improved, not durable enough.
