title: 72 hour timer is Irritating

author: Dina
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on February 13, 2021
review_content: That's right- I am on my second Bestway Salupa Miami. The previous one lasted for almost three years and I figure that's pretty good longevity for an inflatable. Besides I already know that the customer service at Bestway is outstanding. The heater pump took a dump 8 months in with the last tub, still under warranty and they sent out a new pump immediately without hassle.The newly purchased tub is a better design- even easier setup (less components) heats up quicker and seems to hold the heat better too. I did use the top cover material from the old tub to insulate/protect the bottom, so that may be a factor. Also I placed the tub under a covered deck and that way it's not as vulnerable to the elements. The manual says that it's not a good idea to operate the tub in below freezing temperatures but I think having a shelter for it may allow for a little bending of those rules. It just snowed here for the first time this winter; it's been 28°F at night for a week and all seems to be fine. The tub isn't sitting perfectly level either. The cement of the patio is at a slight decline, maybe a couple of inches, but doesn't seem to affect operation or stability.I learned a few good tricks with my 1st tub so apply them to the new one in hopes that I can make it last possibly longer.The filter needs to be taken out and sprayed clean frequently, the more the better. It's important to stay on top of this to insure smooth running/longevity of the heater pump. Avoid getting in the tub with dirty feet or any other risk of adding debris. Have a pool skimmer handy just in case.I really like the little chemical dispenser that adheres to the outflow inside the tub so you dont have to have a floater. I keep a steady supply of 1 bromine tablet cut in half and it keeps the water crystal clear and doesn't smell.Another rule of thumb: its inflatable- therefore important to keep glass, curious animals, children or any sharp objects far away and be gentle getting in/out of the tub. It IS very thick and sturdy but once you have a hole that's when the trouble begins. Even if you can locate and fix the leak it's difficult to keep it fully inflated. The last 6 months of having my last tub my cat suddenly jumped up on the top side to visit me and punctured the most vulnerable part of the vinyl. I was able to fix but as time went on was hand-pump inflating it more and more then just gave up and got a new one.I have been using the new one almost every night for over 2 months now. The "floor" is also more attractive, more padded and  more comfortable than the previous. So far, so GREAT!The spa temperature reaches to 104°F and its a perfect thrill to get in every time. The "jets" (just bubbles) are fun too, although the temp goes down quickly when they are on. The timer is a really nice feature. I usually sit in the tub around 9pm for about 20 minutes and then when I get out I set the timer for 8 hours. It automatically shuts off early morning and has a chance to "rest", the temp goes down to around 93°F, I turn it back on set to 104°F again when I leave for work then when I get home it's ready when I'm ready.Keep in mind that this is NOT a 4 person tub. Two adult lovers snuggling is maybe the limit, but in my opinion it's best to experience solo.All in all it's a good purchase as long as the price threshold doesn't go beyond $500. Selling sites keep fluctuating between $400 and a whopping $900.Considering that you dont pay too much, you have an adequate, low maintenance one to two person spa for minimum $$ per year. That's not a bad deal!
title: Loved this spa so much I bought it twice

review_content: I purchased and set up this tub and I couldn't be happier with it.  It is a great value for the price.  I just wish it would have been paired with an appropriate chemical starter kit, rather than Brom Tabs and Bright & Clear.  As a first time spa owner, I had to teach myself how to start a Bromine tub and balance everything.  If there were some sort of kit that offered Brom Start, pH up & down, Calcium, test strips, Brom tabs, etc., it would have been a perfect experience.  It's not the tub manufacturer's fault though, they get 5 stars.  Boo on Amazon for not pairing this item with the chemicals and tests that you need!EDIT: Second year setup was a lot easier and we are enjoying our tub immediately, now that I am a professional hot tub chemist.  This item was a great value for the money especially now that we are using it again this season.
title: So far, so great!

author: CAT
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on February 12, 2021
review_content: Best thing I have bought in a very long time. The strength of the bubbles blew me away. Easy to put up and start using. Mine is outside and I keep an added comforter on it when really cold. It holds the temp night and day. I do have a tent over it since it has been so rainy. I get in after workouts and has helped with soreness and just feels fantastic. Sooooo worth the money!

author: Carmen Manous
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on April 21, 2021
review_content: This Miami Saluspa is AMAZING. I did A LOT of research about the Portable Hot Tubs. This brand kept coming up as one of the best brands. I am More than Pleased. I didn't think that the jets would be as strong as they are. I thought the bottom would be hard, like sitting on the ground, but it wasn't.  It has a gel like bottom. author: Andrew Jensen
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on January 12, 2021
review_content: I bought this after doing a lot of research on and I believed that this would be a good purchase. I keep the hot tub in my basement in the winter, and for the first season, it worked WONDERFULLY! I really enjoyed it as did my whole family.BUT THEN, I pack it up for the spring and summer, and get it out to get it ready in the fall, and the pump trips it built in GFCI on start up. Turns out the heater element was burnt out. I filed a warranty claim in November, and within a couple weeks I had a new pump.NOW that I have the new pump, the spa liner is beginning to deteriorate at an alarming rate. It is losing many gallons of water a day, and I have to inflate it daily lest the wall completely collapse.I attempted to file another warranty claim, and was promptly rejected. BUYERS BEWARE: This spa liner only has a 6 month warranty!!! The pump had 1 month, but I find 6 months to be pretty ridiculous.I will attempt to find a solution to patching and finding the holes myself, but I believe them to be on the seams and it will be pretty difficult.I am saddened to write all this because I really enjoyed this for one season, and if that is somehow all you're looking to get out of this purchase, then I highly recommend it.But if you'd like something that you can use for more than 1 year, I would have to stay, STEER CLEAR.

author: Jeff
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on February 23, 2021
review_content: This has been one of the best investments I’ve ever made. For under $500, it provides a really relaxing experience. The timer works well, but it’s best if you anticipate the weather. Obviously, colder outside air temperature will take longer for the water to warm up. It’s probably not recommended, but we have put in cost of boiling water which helps the temperature rise more quickly. It also means in excess of water so the next time will have to empty out buckets of water. Don’t expect high end temperature feel. I am pretty easily pleased, so 104 is plenty warm for me. If it was offered, I would probably pay a little more for one that went up to 108 or 110°.The set up was pretty easy. They recommend switching out the water fairly often, but so far I have emptied it once and cleaned it really well sense early January. I think switching out the water once every 5-6 weeks with some gentle cleaning and mild chemicals (bromine tablets and ph up/down) is the right frequency with how often we use out tub (3x/week). Overall, I’d say this is a great investment.
title: Best investment yet

author: Carolyn Richardson
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on April 17, 2021
review_content: I recently bought this after realizing my body was aching from working from home for the last 13 months due to the Covid pandemic, and I don’t have any bathtubs in my house that are good for soaking in. It got delivered promptly, within 36 hours. They might want to warn about the weight but I just took everything out of the box and the individual pieces were manageable. Set up is pretty easy AFTER you look for a YouTube video - the pictorial instructions that are included are complete crap. I still have a couple of parts that I have no idea what they do or where they go as they are never shown in the manual other than as an included part, or in the videos I watched. If you think Ikea furniture is difficult, these instructions are not for you. However, once I got everything seemingly in the right place, it turned on nicely and heated up from about 72 degrees for the water temp to 102 within 24 hours. I still need to figure out how to open the filter container - it was shown in one video but I haven’t managed to actually open it that way, so an easier opening mechanism on this would be appreciated. I’m not sure if it unscrews or you just pry it open.Let’s be clear this is more suitable as a hot tub, not a jacuzzi. The bubbles do little more than bubble the water and the air pump feature is so loud that having a conversation with other people might be difficult.
title: Good value for the cost, more hot tub than jacuzzi

author: Jamie V.
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on March 20, 2018
review_content: This was the buy of the year! Easily one of the best purchases I've made. We've had the unit for 8wks and use it daily if not multiple times a day. We used to big bath takers but now we just pop into the hot tub whenever we want a soak. The depth is perfect for both myself and my husband even though we have a lot of difference in height. When full and two ppl inside the water is about 3 inches from the shoulder on me (5'4) and at armpit level for my husband (6'3). The filters are easy to find and can be very inexpensive if you keep an eye on Amazon. I just got a 12pk for $30. The filters last a month if you clean them regularly. I use the floating frog spa system and I always have good bromine levels with practically no work. The heater and timer function work great and let me tell you, this thing pumps out some bubbles! The pump unit does pull a lot of amperage so beware when plugging into a wall outlet that is already heavily used. We can't use our microwave when the heater is on or we blow a fuse. review_content: UPDATE:...we had to buy a 2nd one..2018....1st one worked great for about 3 years....but somehow got a air leak...we could not find where it was...and the seals inside the tube hook ups went bad...so we got another one...the pump on the 1st one still works so we will use that one with the new spa and keep the new pump for backup..we still think this spa is a great value and nice to just relax in............................FILTERS::: dont just use them and throw them away !!!!!...waste of money....when our filters get dirty...we keep them in a bucket of water...and when we can get to them...we use a stream sprayer at the end of the hose and spray them clean again...wahla...new filters again....but after awhile...they do get pretty beat up...and then we put in new filters....will save you tons of money on replacing filters every two weeks...we can make a set of filters last a few months b4 we have to put in new ones...just a thought for ya all...  ........OLD REVIEWS....thou we bought this few months ago, we finally got deck built and got spa up and running...works great, even in this cold weather, 20 degrees, we just need to keep the heating on at night so it dont freeze...but only bad thing i dont like........ is when we want the water hot, it takes a good 24 hours to heat up...other than that, this spa is worth the money, compared to those solid ones...easy to put up, jets work great, but when they are on, it does cool the water down a bit...but dont help that its winter ... 2nd review-----2017  ...well still have the spa and its still working great...its winter time again...and cant wait to get into it , great when snow on the ground and the spa is all steamy...

date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on January 22, 2021
review_content: Seems to have a hard time maintaining temperature, as others have noticed. review_content: Missed out a black friday deal for a similar inflatable hot tub. Got this one for $150 less than regular price. Setup was quick and painless. review_content: I order a lot of stuff from Amazon and never write reviews, but I feel this product deserves one since it is one of the best purchases I've ever made. This is a great hot tub. The temp will drop much faster if you use the massaging air.The filtration system works well, but be sure to buy some extra filters with the tub, as they only last a week or two.   Coleman Lay-Z Spa Replacement Cartridges (12)          Also be sure to buy a good test kit.   Poolmaster 22260 5-Way Test Kit with Case - Basic Collection           All I use is muriatic acid, unscented bleach, and a little baking soda and you're good to go. review_content: This is money well spent! Hot tub works great. There were a few questions I had before buying it. I searched Amazon reviews and couldn't find the answer. I thought I would post them below.Q: How much electricity does this hot tub use.A: about 12.5 Kilowatts per day that is leaving it at 102 degrees and using it 30 min a day indoors. I just got my electric bill and only saw about a $15 increase. The Power usage is about 1300 watts when heating, 600 Watts for blower.Q: Is the Air cold that is being use to make the jets run?A: Yes but you only notice it when you put your Hands right above the jet's it's cold. At 102 degrees I can use it for 30 min and it drops to about 99. Works great for me.Q: What chemicals do I use?A: I bought chlorine granules on Amazon. Use about 1/2 tablespoon every 3 days. I did buy Spa Down as my water has a High PH. That seems to be working. Also living in MN our water has lots of dissolved minerals in it. I did use Soft Water as we have so much iron in our water and my Alkalinity level is high but I have not had a problem with it. I still may take my water to a spa dealer to have it tested.Couple of things to note:-It does loose air when tub is inflated for a few weeks. I didn't need to add air as the water keeps it up. It was not a problem. Just the sides get a little soft.-The pump will not work if water is too cold. I just filled my tub after being gone for a few weeks. Since it is now -0 in MN our water coming from the city was at 46 degrees. The pump would error out. I had to wait for the water to warm up to room temp then the pump worked fine. The first time I filled it in Oct. the pump worked fine and the water was about about 56 degrees. Just so you know if you get an error.- Temp fluctuation. Remember the heater will not work when the jet's are on. Also it has a 4 degree temp swing. For example if you set it to 102 the temp could be between 100-104. So if you really want 104 you may need to go look at the spa a few hours before you use it and turn off the heater and back on to kick in the heat.I love this spa! It has a few issues. But nothing that would stop me from buying another one.

During the following 6 hours, with the air temp reaching 50 degrees, the heat loss was a mere 5 degrees or approximately 1 degree per hour.  I can accept losing 5 cents/hr heat loss, based on 10 cents/hr to increase the water temp two degrees.  With an air temp of 51 the outer sidewall was 54.  I was hoping  to keep the outer sidewall within a few degrees of the air temp.  Yes, the pump is too noisy but I have no intentions of utilizing that "water cooler".  There are several methods to create a genuine water jet inside the tub.  Photos illustrate a 4 hour process to substantially lessen heat loss.  The top cover now boasts three additional layers;  floating blue bubble blanket, double layer of R1 (1/4" foam) and 2" of standard styro. The white styro inserts flush with the top of the tub like a tight lid.  The inflatable top rests on a support (white trellis) which spans the top of the sidewalls.  The side wall wrap is two layers of blue bubble insulation  with a single panel  1/4" foam sandwiched in between.  Strongly suggest users also enhance the floor padding with memory foam, carpet padding,  convoluted mattress pads or anything you might have available.  There is no need to dwell on the shortcomings of customer service given the fact many reviews address that issue.  The tub only shows one band securing the sidewall wrap.  Several more support bands were added afterwards.  I prefer granular chlorine to tablets.  A few tablespoons lasted two weeks.The manual, DVD, or parts list did not reference the 5 foot clear hose that came with the unit.  The purpose became obvious after the unit was leaking water through the second filter housing. The hose connects the filter to the main housing intake at the Y connection.  The  Y connection was not shown.
